prop.head.headtext: Thorburn, Law of Confidential Business Information

prop.head.label.name: Chapter
prop.head.headtext: Defences to Claims for Breach of Confidential Business Information

head.headtext: Right of the Public to Be Informed

para.paratext: The courts have broadened the grounds for the dissemination of confidential business information not only to include the prevention of illegal or improper activities but, in some circumstances, to also allow for dissemination of information which would protect the public interest by ensuring that products used by the public meet the appropriate standard of care.

In Lion Laboratories Ltd. v. Evans,[1] the plaintiffs manufactured and marketed a breathalyzer device which measured the blood-alcohol level of drivers by testing their breath. The defendants were technicians who worked on the instrument. They left the plaintiff's employ, taking with them confidential documents that cast doubt on the accuracy of the device. These documents were eventually published in a newspaper (which was also named as a defendant), with the rationale that the public should be informed since the instrument's test results alone could have led to charges and convictions for drunk driving.
The court in Lion Laboratories rejected the “no iniquity, no public interest” rule and stated that there were two competing interests in a case of this nature:
the right of the organization (or individuals) to keep secret confidential information; and
the right of the public to be informed of confidential information.

Where the second factor outweighs the first, the confidential information will be allowed to be disseminated. In this case, most of the documents in question were allowed to be published because: “The plaintiffs … owe a grave obligation to the public to ensure that the machine is produced and maintained to the highest standards.”[2]

In Woodward v. Hutchins,[3] the court held that the public interest in learning that the conduct of public figures was inappropriate outweighed the individuals' right to maintain the confidentiality of the information. However, where the conduct amounted to no more than an error in judgment on the part of the government, the court refused to grant an order for disclosure of the confidential documents on the grounds that there was no justification.
Lion Laboratories Ltd. v. Evans, [1984] 3 W.L.R. 539 (C.A.).
Lion Laboratories Ltd. v. Evans, [1984] 3 W.L.R. 539 (C.A.), at p. 560.
Woodward v. Hutchins, [1977] 2 All E.R. 751 (CA). See also High-Rise Group Inc. v. Canada (Minister of Public Works) (2004), 238 D.L.R. (4th) 44, 30 C.P.R. (4th) 417 (F.C.A.).
